Bottle shared by Shoulderbroken. Thanks! Beautiful crimson pour with white lace. Huge fruit-forward nose: raspberry, cranberry, cherry, with yogurt and vanilla. Big, lovely fruit flavors, very sweet, but tangy too. Fruit all the way, and very tasty, though the barrel character is not coming out as much as I would prefer. I think it is still too young-fruit absolutely dominates. Great to try, and want to try again in a couple years.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2016 Red and mahogany color. Tons of raspberries, cranberries and cherries in the nose, but slightly sweet, not sour. Earthy and woody.  Much more sour in the mouth, tart cherries, cranberries and raspberries in mouth. Earth sour cherry and raspberry finish. tartness has gone down after five years and complexity has gone up. Decent stuff.

Bottle 750ml. [Batch 2]
Pours red/brownish with almost no head. Aroma is of fruits, sweet, sour, red licorice, candies. Taste is sour, sweet, cherries, sour candies. Palate: Ligth-medium body. Overall: Very good. Not too cloying. Intense red fruits.

Bottle at ChrisO tasting, from De Bier Tempel, Brugges, 30/12/12.
Hazed reddish brown with no head.
Nose is cherries, wood, sugars, berry fruits.
Taste comprises wood, cherries, cherry menthol drops, lightly medicinal (in a good way).
Smooth on the palate, minimal carbonation, spot on!
Excellent stuff !

text:
Close to perfect. Lovely, lively berry notes with raspberry dominating, vinous, tart, refreshing, great colour and mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A steady pour into my Bruery tulip produces a two finger thick, pale pink tinged, pale tan colored head. The beer is a concentrated red color, not unlike a dark cherry; when held up to the light the beer shows a light haze, and a bright red hue. The beer has a touch of a childrens aspirin type fruitiness to it, perhaps even a bit like fake Concord Grape, but really the bright, lush raspberry character is the dominant note to the aroma. I believe the cranberry character is noticeable here, towards the end it smells like sweet cranberry juice a bit, the cherry plays a supporting role to the raspberries helping to give them more of a rounded, berry like character.

The beer starts out a little dry up front, but picks up a sweetness pretty quickly which lingers on the palate through to the finish where the acidity finally dries things out again. Not as sweet as I was expecting, Alexander was sweeter, but it certainly could be quite a bit drier as well. The sweetness accentuates the fruit character, once again raspberries are prominent, but the cherries are much more noticeable in the flavor, including a bright, flavorful cherry skin character, while I dont specifically recognize the cranberry notes. There is lots of acidity here, the cranberries definitely contribute to this, as do the cherries and raspberries, the base beer contributes most of the acidity though, with a lactic acidity providing a rounded note and a hint of acetic character providing some additional bite. The beer definitely has a childrens aspirin flavor to it, especially in the finish at times, and this also seems a bit chalky in the texture at times. The beer is fairly light bodied, it definitely has some heft to it, but somehow the fruit character makes it seem lighter than it might otherwise be. The oak is light, but provides some firmness to both the flavor and the texture, though it is not overtly noticeable.

This is definitely a fruit focused beer, not nearly as cloying as the New Glarus Fruit beers, and not as fruit rich as some traditional Lambics. I wish that more of the base beer came through, the rich caramelized maltiness, and the firmness of the base beer is certainly missed here with this fruit focus. Still note a bad beer in the end, just one that has much more potential.
December 29, 2012 - bottle at Bretts tasting. Rose red pour with limited head.  Fruity (cherry & raspberry), dry and bubbly.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a reddish color with a white head. The aroma has some light vinegar notes, as well as some sour cherries, toffee and light funk. The flavor is similar. The sour cherries and funk come through up front. There is also some toffee and vinegar in the flavor. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bottle (750 ml) batch #2. Reddish-brown with ruby highlights and small quickly diminishing head. Aroma of red fruits, wood, slight sourness and, as stated before by JulienHuxley, slight weird notes of menthol. Taste is an explosion of red fruits (raspberries, cherries and cranberries), slight sweetness, wood and slight sourness. Light to medium body. Soft carbonation. Mouthfeel is winey. Another very good beer by Rodenbach and lots of similarities with Rodenbach Alexander. Very complex and probably one of the most fruity beer Ive tasted so far.
Bottle at Chriso New Year 2012/13.  clear red almost no head. pippy raspberry aroma lovely. sour beer thats good. locely pippy wild srawberry. bit of funk on aroma. really good

Bottle. Clear red body with an averaged sized, quickly diminishing off-white (pink) head. Aroma/taste: strong flavours of balsamic vinegar, sourness, strawberries, vinous, barnyard, slightly acidic. Light bodied, moderate carbonation.
Bottle. Deep ruby maroon color, small tan head that settles quickly. Aroma of plums and cherries. Taste is sour and slightly acetic cherry, blueberry, dates.

Bottle. Clear red pour, smallish head. Aroma is ultra fruity, nice blend of cherry and raspberry, some cough syrup notes, menthol, light oxidization. Taste is perfectly sour and fruity, really well balanced, just perfect, I could drink it all day. Palate is tart and dry but medium bodied with soft carbonation. The aroma is a little off but this beer is delicious.

75cl bottle. Brown and clear liquid with small, lightly red head. Nose : pickled cherries, wood notes and other cooked fruit aromas. Some little tart also mingles into this bouquet. Sip : the body is oily and it sparks are very fine, the same as a fruit compote lightly fermented. The taste is remarkable. Many different layers ; it attacks with a strong sweet and sour fruity flavor and adds up sour and a bit dry wooden notes. Overall, the alcohol brings out the red wine character to it. It goes dry very close to how the red wine does. Aftertaste is continuing with sourness and sweetness in the background. Nice experience.

Pretty sure this is batch 1, best by 05/06/2015, opened for my 30th bday!  Ruby red, deep pigment; delicate lace and head.

Pungent fruits in the nose: can clearly smell all 3 fruits (cherries, raspberries, cranberries).  Kiss of sweetness in the nose balances against the inherent sourness from the fruit.  Really nice.

Intense, puckering sourness on the palate as freshly picked fruits bum-rush my taste buds.  Highly concentrated flavor, brimming at the rim with deliciousness.  Certainly too intense for some, but I simply cannot get enough.  Will be aging my other bottle for at least a year to see how it develops.

Corked bottle from Kraddel, thanks! Ruby red color. Cherries, raspberries and cranberries in the aroma. Sour with some fruit sugars. Lots of berries. Oak. Hint of marzipan. Complex and enjoyable beer.

75cl bottle from Kurt,Belgiuminabox.All to myself!
Poured a lovely ruby red colour with a small pinkish head.
The Rodenbach vinegar nose is there straight away with a cherry and raspberry aroma hot on its heels.A wet woody smell in there too making it quite mouthwatering.
The cherry and raspberry taste comes through at first and is followed swiftly by a woody vinegar like flavour making a fantastic sweet and sour taste.The berry taste remains quite strong in the aftertaste along with the sourness,great.Another sip or two and the wet wood is there.I really enjoyed this one and really glad to have 3 bottles for sharing at our little beer club sometime in the future.

Pours cherry red with a wispy head.  Nose opens with a Flanders vinegar barrel that I typically dont really enjoy, found in most Rodenbach (less so "Vintage") and other Flemish reds.  A pleasant berry note underneath, perhaps even the cranberry, lightly tart but bright.  Mouth feel is thin and spritzy with very high carbonation, but like a New York Seltzer from back in the day.  Flavors are light and fruit forward, a pleasant marriage of red berries and oak integrated very well.  That vinegar note is light in the mouth, thankfully. Bottle from bieresgourmet.be webshop. I know this is a beer for sharing, but I said to myself: my friend and Ratebeer admin Yngwie deserves a great beer for his honorary rating, celebrating his rating no. 10, 000 in absence since I cant join the party tonight in Kristiansand. Oh well, this ones for you Yngvar! :-) Pours a clear, deep ruby-hued body with a small pink-ish head. Lovely color. Nose is vinegar and acetone-like notes up front, followed by a lovely deep cascade of berries; all three kinds surfacing gently, dancing around in my nostrils. Nice. Hints of wood and caramel malt sweetness far in the back, but lacto-bacterial tartness and berries dominate for the most. Taste is finely tuned sweet berry notes at first, followed by really tart vinegar and acetone tones; then woody malt tones before a crisp, sweet-sour finish rounds the party off with style. The berries hang around in the aftertaste with a healthy dose of sourness, beckoning another sip. Palate is kind of fizzy but not really disturbing since it propels the taste in a rather enjoyable fashion. All in all a very fruity and lovely berry-focused sour ale. Highly recommendable and definitely worthy as a tribute rating to the RB King of Norway: Yngwie! Hail thee and CHEERS! :-D

Aroma of raspberry, violet flower, cassis, cherry vinegar and almond and almond paste/frangipane (when warmed up). Light to medium body with a fresh sour sweetness, taste is cherries. Ideal drinking temperature is cellar temperature. Nice beer, but I dsoubt that all fruit is natural; there is a tad sweetness that is akward. But overall a very nice beer

An absolutely astonishing and suprising beer. Not at all what I expected from the Rodenbach name. This beer has elements of Rodenbach but also is very much like a fruit lambic. Nose is strong with the typical Rodenbach character and a touch of cherry and cranberry. It isnt until you taste the beer that its full power becomes apparent. Quite acidic but extremely well balanced. More like an american sour than the typical flemish red it has far less of the vinegar notes in a typical rodenbach. Instead the back half the the beer is dominated by huge notes of cranberry, cherry and raspberry. Moderately sweet but sour enough to achieve near perfect balance, this beer is really only lacking in the nose, and note because the nose is bad in any ways, but just because it simply doesnt match the incredible flavor. Probably the best Rodenbach I have ever had, and Ive had them all at this point. Huge thanks to hopscotch for sharing this.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2013 Bottle (Batch 1)... This beer rocks! Cloudy caramel-colored ale with orange highlights and a small fizzy, off-white head that never fully dissipates. The bouquet is crazy fruity; providing cherries, loads of acidity, caramel, vanilla, raspberry and red currants with a light splash of pinot noir vinegar.  Medium to full bodied and super creamy with prickly carbonation. The flavor is every bit as fantastic as Alexander, but so much more fruity. Both acidic and acetic, this brew presents notes of caramel, raspberry and cherry, accompanied by a dainty splash of red wine vinegar. Sour, fruity, puckering finish.  Mathieu87 provided this world class bottle of beer!

Bottle at Denis. Vivid reddish brown, thin white head. Barley, hint of that Rodenbah balsanic vinegar thing, rich tart fruits, funky cherry skin, tart raspberry, vinous sourness on the nose. Soft supple sourness, light tartness in the linger. Awesome!

Bouteille de 750 ml, merci beaucoup à Dany et Marie-France. Arômes intenses de fruits rouges, on distingue particulièrement les cerises et les framboises. Belle présence vineuse. Robe rousse et limpide, effervescence assez active mais peu de mousse. En bouche, on retrouve le caractère classique de la Rodenbach, avec une présence de caramel et un côté vineux et vinaigré. Les fruits sont très intenses et on identifie vraiment la contribution des trois variétés utilisées. Finale plutôt sucrée et acide. Une belle bière, plutôt originale.

Ruby red color. Small off-white, pink tinged head that quickly falls and leaves no lacing behind. A very nice mixture of tea, cherries and a sour funk in the nose. A slight hint of raspberry. Very sour cherry flavor with a nice peppery presence. A tart finish with a big hint of fruit. Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2013 75cl (3rd Batch), new exclusive brew Anno 2011, with cherries, raspberries and cranberries, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex sour fruit brew, fruity/sour and slightly woody/vinous, balanced, clear, nearly no head, very good brew, yet expensive

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2012 20cL taste.  Balanced for a "Flanders Red", (as hopscotch point out), pleasant.  I usually hate this type of beer, but this one is different enough from other Rodenbachs that Ive tried that I like it a lot.  Im not sure that Im a sour/wild ale guy, though.

15 cl. tasting glass @ Bierpassie Weekend XIII // definitely a beer that I have been interested in for quite a while // ever since it was announced way back probably // this is presumably the 2nd batch of 10.000 bottles // not a bad business strategy for a company like this, small limited edition pricy limited edition for months followed by a relatively big release so that everyone will jump at the bottles & still can adore it for the rare // either way  this sounds quite delicious // bright crimson bordeaux with a small pink head // smell is cherries, fruity cherries pureed with raspberries, berries, tart, picking up raspberries the most, touch underneath wood & acid // taste is quite fruity upfront, natural sweetness from the fruits, firstly & mainly I am getting raspberries here, maybe I can pick up some cherries as well, fruitiness & natural fruit sweetness begin to intertwine with the sharp contours of a sourness going towards acidity, not a full on sour blast of sourness like a real Oud Bruin but sharp contour of an acidity surrounding the fruitiness, elegant like of wood, berry acidity, any berries, not specifically cranberries but those could be mentioned even if they are not as acidic as the fruit itself, more like cranberry juice, the fruits have evened the raw wood & sour malts of the base beer into something more elegant // nice thinner but not thin body, medium to touch softer carb. // bit weirded out about people going on that this tastes like candy, definitely sweeter than you would maybe think but still some sourness to this puppy // more elegant & for the sophisticated masses of which I do not consider myself part as opposed to for instance Foederbeer // the ads are calling this complex over & over, Vintage, Foeder, Grand Cru, are all more complex than this, more fruits doesnt necessary mean more complexity to me // official tasting notes include caramel, violets, leather & light tobacco // unfortunately I am not getting any of that, maybe my pallet is broken // no kriek either, this is cherry // I am however getting raspberry & touches of wood // not sure whether age will elevate this // still undecided on my prognosis for that // good, nice additional but not the highpoint they make it out to be & I secretly was hoping for // cheers

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2012  Always nice to try a special release from Rodenbach, they should be doing more of these experements.
Berries all the way with this one. I smell mostly the cherries, other berries noticed too. Tart, cherry flavour, and then wood, very nice...
But ... then it turns ... sweet, and that is smth we DO NOT want :/
Why the heck did they do with this beer .... not for me.

Ripe berries on the nose, tart raspberries and hints of wood.  Pours a pinkish red with a thin white head and nice lacing as its consumed.  Flavor is tart cranberries with cherries, nicely acidic and the fruit flavors blend great.  An excellent beer!  It was a treat to try it.

Shortlived dirty-pink head over hazed foxy red-copper beer. Intense acids: lactic and acetic, but also lots of red fruit (cherry, raspberry, little scarlets and quite outspoken redcurrant). Zeste of some strange sourish fruit (not so bitter as cranberry). Excellent, fine, but very sharp acidic fruitflavour: raspberry mainly, maybe some cherry, but also more exotic fruit (rosehips, quinces, pink grapefruit, redcurrant). Ends very tart, but the fruitflavours keep going on for minutes. Sharp acidburn, rather light body thanks to the acidthinning. Excellent, but just too acidic to be more than a general 8/10. However,  NOTHING , nothing about this beer could rectify this absolutely RIDICULOUS pricetag of 30 Euro!!

75cl bottle, cheers to ajax25g for sharing this one. Bottle ?/900 no label just a description tag. Had this right after a vintage Vin de Céréale 2004, what a nice contrast between the two.
Couleur cuivrée allant vers un rubis, le tout sur qcq bulles blanches.
Arôme est de fruits rouges, je note plus la framboise qui prend un peu le dessus sur la cerise et canneberge.  Ressent aussi le beau profile du foudre de chêne avec un bouquet prononcé de vinaigre.
En bouche, un profile énorme de vinaigre qui enrobe le palais. Le tout est en addition de laigreur des fruits rouges qui à lorigine sont déjà assez acidulés. Encore ici, je note le framboise plus en avant, suivi juste de la cerise. Canneberge reste plus discrète. Garde bien sur la signature Rodenbach avec ce beau profile boisé de chêne. 
Une aigreur très en avant mais qui convient tout à fait à cette bière et à son niveau dalcool. Se déguste doucement. Pour moi, un vrai plaisir à partager et une belle expérience dans un style qui nest pas assez représenté en Belgique.

75 cl bottle at Waterhuis aan de Bierkant, Gent. Small head over a dark pink beer. Very fruity aroma, vinous, wood and sourness. Taste is mainly raspberries and cranberries. Really packs a sour punch. Only downfall is that the sourness results in a burning throat in the end. Great beer from Rodenbach and excellent as an "apéritif".

Head: small , white pinkish 
Colour: red amberish  
Smell: fruity, sour/ flemish oud bruin , malts , somewhat of red fruits , and a bit of red wine 
Taste: quite a sour one actually , vinegar like , raspberrys, red fruits overall actually , end is dry because of the sourness in the beer , after is fruits, quite a nice one of you like the more sour beers

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2011 5/11/2011 75cl bottle @ De Bistronoom, Oostende (2011-617)
Clear copper to scarlet red beer, small very light pink head. Aroma: very fruity, woody, bit vinous, cranberries. MF: good carbon, medium to full body. Taste: very fruity tart start, raspberries, forest fruits, vinegar, wood. Aftertaste: tart finish, little bitter and vinous. Burns a bit in the throat because of the high acidity.
